title: How to end a sentence that ends with a quote - Quora

response.answer_text: In American English, the rule is always to put the punctuation inside the quotation marks. British punctuation (also known, tellingly, as logical punctuation) gives you a choice. If the quotation is a complete sentence or a major part of one, you should put the punctuation inside the quotation, just as in American English. If it’s just a word or a short phrase, it’s usually prefereable to put the punctuation outside the quotation marks. Jane said she was “fed up.” (US)Jane said she was “fed up”. (UK)If the punctuation influences the meaning or impact of the sentence, like a question mark or exclamation mark, do whatever gives you the meaning you want. There is a difference between Jane said “I’m fed up!”Jane said “I’m fed up”!

If it is a quotation within a sentence, place the last quotation mark before the period. If the quotation is the entire sentence, place the quotation mark after the period. This is, however, the British style. Strunk and White do not agree.
